title: How Texas House Democrats broke quorum, took a congressional redistricting fight national
description: For the past week, the Texas House has been at a standstill after Democrats secretly left the state to block a vote on a partisan gerrymander. They've been...
content:
ST. CHARLES, Ill. — Leaving behind his nearly nine months pregnant wife, Kendall Scudder trekked to Tulsa, Okla., on June 28 to meet with Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker.

Scudder, the newly elected chair of the Texas Democratic Party, arranged to have a private meeting with the governor at the site of a fundraiser for Oklahoma Democrats, where Pritzker was a keynote speaker. One of the topics he wished to broach was a persistent rumor circulating in Austin for months: redistricting.

“I knew that we needed to start forming relationships with partners outside the state in the event that we needed to use those relationships,” Scudder said.

Five weeks later, Scudder had a 2-week-old son, Lyndon — named for the former president and his wife’s father — and an exodus of state House Democrats from Texas was underway, with dozens secretly fleeing to Illinois to block a vote on a partisan gerrymander that could flip as many as five Democratic-held seats to Republican control.

For the past week, the Texas House has been at a standstill after Democrats refused to show up on Aug. 4, denying the chamber a constitutionally required quorum to conduct legislative business. Their move — known as a quorum break — blocked a vote on congressional redistricting sought by President Donald Trump, as well as more than a dozen other items Gov. Greg Abbott placed on a special session agenda — most notably efforts to address the Hill Country floods that killed at least 137 people.

The Dallas Morning News spoke with more than 20 House Democrats and staff who have been decamped in Illinois for the past week. Their accounts offer an inside look at how they decided to employ the nuclear option to block redistricting and how they pushed redistricting into the national spotlight amid Republican backlash and growing security concerns.

Rep. Ramon Romero Jr., D-Fort Worth, said he first heard rumors of redistricting in the early spring. Education policy dominated the session. It seemed there would be little room for something as politically thorny as redistricting.

“No one really took it seriously,” Romero said.

Democrats dismissed the rumors in part because the Legislature approved redistricting in 2021, further solidifying Republican majorities in both chambers of the state Legislature and adding two more seats for Republicans to Washington.

The rumors lulled, but returned in late May during the final weeks of the biennial 140-day session of the Texas Legislature.

Rep. Gene Wu, chair of the House Democratic Caucus, said the session came to a close, and he heard Abbott might try to redistrict Texas in a special session.

After the session ended, Abbott issued an 11th-hour veto of a ban on hemp-derived THC products. Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick was incensed over the torpedoing of what is one of his top legislative priorities. But it also gave Abbott a clear path to call a special 30-day legislative session.

Abbott had made an initial list of items he told lawmakers would appear in an upcoming special session. THC was on the list. Redistricting wasn’t.

But then the July 4 floods came. That, Wu said, was when whispers of redistricting rose to a roar.

“People in the know realized that Abbott would use the Kerrville disaster as cover to do redistricting,” Wu said. “That’s when the hairs on the back of my neck went up and I kind of said, ‘Oh, crap.’”

Abbott spokesman Andrew Mahaleris said in a statement that Democrats’ flight from the state was a “publicity stunt,” and that the governor has “deployed all available resources and support to help communities respond and recover.” Any relief funds, Mahaleris added, would need to be appropriated by the Legislature.

“If Texas House Democrats care about the Texans they abandoned, they will return to Austin and do the job they were elected to do,” he said.

On July 7, the U.S. Department of Justice penned a letter to Abbott and Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton stating that four congressional districts in Texas violated new caselaw on the Voting Rights Act of 1965 that weakened legal claims protecting “coalition districts” — districts in which a combination of nonwhite communities comprises a majority.

Two days later, Abbott called a special session that included redistricting, citing the DOJ letter in his proclamation.

The session began on July 21, and legislative hearings on redistricting started rapidly.

Over nine days, the House and Senate held nine hearings on redistricting. Most occurred before the proposed map was made available to lawmakers and the public. They included hearings in Austin, Houston and Arlington.

At every hearing, lawmakers heard near-universal opposition to the plan. Democrats on the committees lodged bitter complaints, at times calling the effort a racist attempt to disenfranchise people of color. Rep. Chris Turner, D-Grand Prairie, described the public hearings as a “dog and pony show.”

Republican heads of the committees disagreed with the Justice Department’s conclusion that the 2021 maps violated the Voting Rights Act. But those same leaders said the disagreement was a moot point, pointing to U.S. Supreme Court rulings in 2019 and 2024 that stated political gerrymanders were legal as long as race was not taken into account.

“I frankly don’t care what the DOJ letter said, and I think it’s pretty clear that no one does on the prevailing side of this bill,” said the chair of the House redistricting committee, Rep. Cody Vasut, R-Angelton. “This bill was not based off of that DOJ letter. It was based off of political performance.”

When the maps were revealed on July 30 in House Bill 4, the proposal showed redrawn districts that dismantled three urban districts — one each in North Texas, Houston and the Austin/San Antonio area — that heavily favored Democrats. Two South Texas swing districts were reconfigured to be more favorable for Republicans.

If 2024 election results hold true in 2026, Republicans would gain five seats — the exact number Trump had requested.

“The trickery and the power grab became so obvious,” said Rep. Barbara Gervin-Hawkins, a San Antonio Democrat on the House redistricting committee.

The House redistricting committee held one final round of public testimony on the maps before approving and sending them to the House floor. It was during that 15-hour hearing that House Democrats crossed a threshold — enough had agreed they would be willing to leave the state in order to block a vote.

Wu, who fellow House members elected as their caucus chair in 2024, said that as House Democrats weighed whether to break quorum, he stressed that they would make the decision together, not as an edict.

To be sure, Wu said he was in favor of breaking quorum. And in the process, Democrat representatives set up a system of “whips,” representatives who regularly gauged their colleagues’ feelings about breaking a quorum.

When Wu counted 51 members willing to abscond from the state, the whips began making calls telling Democrats to pack their bags.

Rep. Mihaela Plesa was tending her rose and vegetable garden in North Dallas on Friday when she got the call.

“I immediately was taken back to the stories my grandparents told me about how they had to flee Romania and how they had to fight back against fascism,” Plesa said.

Rep. Vince Perez was in his backyard in El Paso playing with his dogs when he got the call on Friday night.

“I was probably one of the last ones to get the call,” the first-term lawmaker said. “As a new member, I’m maybe at the bottom of the totem pole.”

Rep. James Talarico, D-Austin, was studying the maps at his Capitol office on Saturday when he got the call.

“You have to be OK knowing that you’re going to get asked to leave with not a lot of notice,” Talarico said.

Midday Sunday, Aug. 3, Democrats from across the state were en route to Illinois, Massachusetts and New York. By the early evening, their flight became public.

By the time House Democrats were in front of cameras alongside Pritzker, who assisted them by finding lodging and meeting spaces, the backlash had already begun.

Attorney General Ken Paxton said he would “hunt down” absent Democrats. Abbott said he would use the courts to remove them from office if they didn’t return in time for the scheduled vote on the redrawn congressional maps.

After it became clear on Aug. 4 that enough Democrats had left to halt business in the House, Speaker Dustin Burrows issued civil warrants for their arrest that have empowered state law enforcement to detain and force lawmakers to return to the Capitol.

In Illinois, Pritzker hailed House Democrats’ decision to leave the state as a “righteous act of courage.”

In the following days, leading Illinois lawmakers would join them at press conferences in an effort to draw more attention to redistricting. Other Texas Democrats did the same in Massachusetts and New York.

Democrats were scrambling to schedule regular news briefings on their efforts. But then on Wednesday morning, a bomb threat derailed their publicity blitz.

They canceled a news conference with Illinois Sen. Dick Durbin and began reevaluating their security.

It was a rude awakening that came after a pro-Trump media outlet exposed their location on social media. Multiple members said the bomb threat evoked the killing of Minnesota lawmaker Rep. Melissa Hortman and her husband Mark Hortman.

Rep. Donna Howard, D-Austin, had traveled to Illinois with her 4-year-old grandson. Howard is his primary caregiver.

“I would have been scared just for my own self,” Howard said. “To have my grandson here made it especially traumatic, because I would obviously not want to have done anything that would have put him in danger.”

For the next two days, they remained confined to the Q-Center — a spartan conference center in St. Charles where representatives slept on twin-sized beds in rooms that reminded some of tiny cruise ship cabins. In Austin, Abbott filed paperwork with the Texas Supreme Court to remove Wu from office. Paxton announced an investigation into how Democrats were paying for their travels.

Sen. John Cornyn contacted the FBI, calling on the federal law enforcement agency to track down House Democrats.

The extent of the FBI’s work is unclear. The agency has declined to comment. Cornyn said agents in San Antonio and Austin were activated to assist state law enforcement.

Some Democrats said the threats only steeled their resolve. Others called it bullying.

Gervin-Hawkins, the chair of the House Black Caucus, wondered whether Republicans’ actions might cause permanent damage in a chamber where friendships form across party lines despite stark differences on policy.

“How can I face colleagues who are now trying to put a target on my back for getting hurt or for getting me arrested, and say that’s OK?” she said.

At a bricklayers’ union hall in Elmhurst, Ill., on Friday, House Democrats held their first public appearance since the bomb threat and Cornyn’s announcement that the FBI was tracking them.

The day before, they had secretly moved their operations from the Q-Center to an undisclosed location in the Chicago area.

Their press event was muted. Its location was only provided to media members who they had verified. At least two Democrats left in the middle of the event. And by its end, lawmakers and their staff outnumbered news media nearly 2-to-1.

House Democrats are cognizant that even if they can stop redistricting during this special session, Abbott has the ability to call another session immediately. The governor has said as much and mused that Republicans could seek to flip even more congressional seats if Democrats continue to push back.

Talarico, who is mulling seeking the Democratic nomination for U.S. Senate in 2026, said the quorum break has delayed his decision on whether he will jump into the race. When asked about how Democrats would respond to repeated special sessions, he referenced the 2021 quorum break.

Democrats had fled to Washington to stop a sweeping conservative election bill. When they finally returned, some of Democrats’ most reviled pieces of policy had been stripped from the bill.

“By shining a national and international spotlight on that voter suppression bill, it pressured Texas Republicans to take the worst parts out,” he said.

Rep. Vikki Goodwin, an Austin Democrat running for lieutenant governor, said that Democrats have at least slowed down redistricting.

“The more that people become aware of the situation, the more that will have an impact in the 2026 elections,” Goodwin said.

At the bricklayers’ union hall, Goodwin watched a livestream of House Democrats’ main event of the day. About 2,000 miles away in Sacramento, Calif., Gov. Gavin Newsom, alongside a handful of Texas Democrats, said his state would redistrict its seats to counteract anything done in Texas.

Newsom was the first of several blue state governors that House Democrats have lobbied to definitively state he would pursue a partisan gerrymander in favor of Democrats. Democratic House members also visited New York Gov. Kathy Hochul.

Vice President JD Vance headed to Indiana last week to lobby for that state to pursue redistricting. Republicans in Florida have also begun an effort to redraw congressional lines.

Texas Democrats have said redrawing districts in their state would trigger a redistricting arms race. That now appears to be underway.

This move effectively blocked a vote on congressional redistricting, which could result in as many as five Democratic-held seats being flipped to Republican control. The Texas Democratic Party's new chair, Kendall Scudder, had a baby son with whom he was meeting with, Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker. The move pushed redistricting into the national spotlight amid Republican backlash and security concerns. The U.S. Department of Justice has written a letter to Abbott and Attorney General Ken Paxton alleging that four congressional districts in Texas violated the Voting Rights Act of 1965. The special session began on July 21 and began rapidly and public hearings on redistricting.

AUSTIN — The deadly Hill Country floods, congressional redistricting and the consumable hemp industry are among the top issues for Texas lawmakers when they convene for a special session later this month, according to a proclamation issued Wednesday by Texas Gov. Greg Abbott.
The Republican governor highlighted several areas lawmakers should consider when seeking to address the devastating July 4 flooding along the Guadalupe River, including legislation that would:
- improve early warning systems and infrastructure in flood zones;
- beef up emergency communications;
- provide relief funding for the affected areas, including federal matching dollars;
- and update or streamline state preparedness and recovery procedures.
“We delivered on historic legislation in the 89th Regular Legislative Session that will benefit Texans for generations to come,” Abbott said in the proclamation. “There is more work to be done, particularly in the aftermath of the devastating floods in the Texas Hill Country. We must ensure better preparation for such events in the future.”
Abbott included those issues on a list of 18 agenda items that lawmakers are expected to address in the session starting July 21.
The list also includes abortion restrictions, limiting transgender rights, throwing out the state’s standardized education tests, increasing the powers of the Texas Attorney General to prosecute state election crimes, banning taxpayer-funded lobbying and further reducing property taxes, among other issues that stymied lawmakers during their regular session earlier this year.
Several state House Republicans immediately cheered Abbott’s proclamation. Rep. Nate Schatzline, R-Fort Worth, called it “BOLD,” while Rep. Caroline Harris Davila, R-Round Rock, said she was “grateful to [Abbott] for adding these critical priorities to the special session call.”
Several Democrats criticized Abbott for including redistricting in a session they said should be focused on addressing the deadly floods.
“It’s disgusting political gamesmanship at a time where every person in our state is reeling over what has happened to the heart of Texas,” Texas Democratic Party Chair Kendall Scudder said in a phone interview. “It’s going to suck all the oxygen out of the room at a time when Texans desperately need leadership. You should never look for leadership in Greg Abbott. He’s a total clown.”
Only Abbott can call a special session of the Legislature, and there is no limit to how many he can call in between the biennial regular sessions. Each special session can last up to 30 days.
The July 4 floods along the Guadalupe River have killed nearly 120 people, including 27 girls from a beloved summer camp, Camp Mystic, in Hunt. More than 160 remain missing.
State leaders are already suggesting ways to avoid similar tragedies in the future, with Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick leading the charge on state-funded warning sirens and lawmakers taking second looks at past attempts to develop statewide mitigation plans and other ideas.
Earlier in the day, Abbott ordered flags flown at half-staff in honor of the victims and their families.
Congressional redistricting
The Legislature will also undertake a mid-decade redistricting of congressional seats. It was an effort pushed by the White House, driven by fears that Republicans could lose their slim majority in the House of Representatives in next year’s midterm elections.
The White House has pushed for aggressive redistricting in hopes of electing as many as five more Republicans to Congress, according to a New York Times report. Republicans currently hold a 25-to-12 advantage over Democrats among the state Congressional delegation. One seat has remained vacant after the death of Houston Rep. Sylvester Turner. That seat is in a deeply blue district.
It will be the first mid-decade redistricting effort since the Texas Legislature redrew Congressional lines in 2003. That effort prompted a walk-out from state Senate Democrats.
Ultimately, it led to Texas Republicans gaining a majority in the state’s congressional delegation for the first time since Reconstruction. The GOP has not relinquished that majority since.
The White House did not immediately return an email seeking comment.
Abbott said in his proclamation that lawmakers should consider an updated plan “in light of constitutional concerns raised by the U.S. Department of Justice.”
The Justice Department flagged four left-leaning seats in a letter sent to Abbott on Monday, raising concerns over the legality of their racial makeup.
Redistricting would target Reps. Marc Veasey, D-Fort Worth; Al Green, D-Houston; Sylvia Garcia, D-Houston; and the vacant Houston seat formerly held by Turner.
Consumable hemp
The call for the special session also includes a directive to lawmakers to take a look at how it can rein in and regulate the state’s burgeoning consumable hemp industry without destroying the $8 billion market boasting some 8,500 retailers and a reported 55,000 employees.
A ban on all those products — gummies, vapes, snacks, drinks and smokable flowers — containing tetrahydrocannabinol, the psychoactive compounding in marijuana, passed the legislature in May.
It was vetoed a month later by Abbott, who said the legislation, Senate Bill 3, was unconstitutional and made criminals out of those who turned to the low-THC products when they couldn’t access the state’s medical marijuana program.
Abbott said lawmakers should not only limit consumable hemp products to customers 21 and up, but also “comprehensively regulate hemp-derived products, including limiting potency, restricting synthetically modified compounds, and establishing enforcement mechanisms, all without banning a lawful agricultural commodity.”
State-mandated STAAR test
Abbott called for legislation that would “eliminate the STAAR test and replace it with effective tools to assess student progress and ensure school district accountability.”
In May, the Texas House passed a bill that would have replaced the controversial STAAR test with a series of three shorter exams administered throughout the school year. But the Senate passed a version that maintained the state’s authority to administer a replacement test overseen by the Texas Education Agency.
The two chambers could not reach an agreement on how to scrap the test by the session’s June 2 deadline.
The STAAR test — which public school students must take in various subjects beginning in the third grade — has faced years of criticism that it is stressful and unhelpful for educators. The House’s revamped testing schedule would relieve pressure on students and provide teachers with real-time data on how kids are learning, lawmakers said.
Annual student testing is required by federal law. Texas’ academic accountability system — which grades every public school in the state on an A-F rating scale — is largely based on STAAR scores. Poor results can lead to consequences for school districts, including a state takeover.
Texas AG powers
The special session call includes legislation that would allow Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton to prosecute state election crimes. Earlier this year, Paxton urged the Legislature to pass a bill that would restore his authority to prosecute election crimes, a power the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals ruled in 2022 he did not have.
Though opponents insisted a constitutional amendment was necessary to give Paxton such authority, lawmakers pursued a bill to restore his powers. That proposal made it to conference in the final days of the regular session, but lawmakers failed to reach an agreement in time to send the bill to the governor.
Abortion
Abbott included a vague call for lawmakers to pass legislation “further protecting unborn children and their mothers from the harm of abortion,” a charge that leaves the door wide open to anti-abortion legislation.
The Legislature passed two priority abortion bills during the regular session: one clarifying the state’s abortion ban exception to protect the mother’s life and another closing what Republican lawmakers described as a loophole that allowed the cities of Austin and San Antonio to give taxpayer money to abortion assistance groups.
But an expansive proposal to ban abortion pill access never made it to Abbott’s desk and will likely be the focus of any related bills during the special session.
Bathroom ban
The special session will also tackle legislation that would require people to use certain private spaces — such as bathrooms — that align with their sex assigned at birth.
During the regular legislative session, a Senate bill dubbed the Texas Women’s Privacy Act sailed out of the upper chamber but didn’t receive a committee hearing in the House. State Sen. Mayes Middleton, the Galveston Republican who authored the bill, on Wednesday thanked Abbott for including that item on the special session’s agenda.
Trans Texans and their allies, however, have previously said such legislation would harm the community’s safety and well-being.
Mila Surjadi, Alex Nguyen, Aarón Torres and Nolan D. McCaskill contributed to this report.

AUSTIN — Texas Gov. Greg Abbott struck down a proposed statewide ban on gummies, vapes and other consumables containing THC on Sunday, calling the ban unconstitutional and ordering lawmakers into a special session in late July.
Sunday’s late-night decision came just minutes before the midnight deadline for Abbott to veto bills passed during the regular session that ended June 2.
Legislators now must figure out how to rein in the $8 billion industry without killing its 55,000 jobs, Abbott said in an extensive veto proclamation.
The regular session’s bill was “well-intentioned,” he explained, but has legal problems that would keep it in litigation for years, delaying measures that could regulate the industry.
The bill opposes federal law and threatens to make felons out of farmers, pharmacists, veterans and parents, Abbott wrote. It could allow for the unconstitutional taking of private property — namely from the “responsible” growers, manufacturers and retailers who opened legal businesses and invested millions into the industry that was legal at the time, he said.
“We can do better,” Abbott wrote. “Texas must enact a regulatory framework that protects public safety, aligns with federal law, has a fully funded enforcement structure, and can take effect without delay.”
Abbott, a Republican, stayed quiet for most of his 10 years in office on the issue of medicinal or recreational THC, or tetrahydrocannabinol, the psychoactive compound in marijuana.
Abbott’s long-anticipated veto of Senate Bill 3 — championed by the Republican Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick and law enforcement across Texas — saved an $8 billion industry with 55,000 employees from being wiped out in six months.
The governor said he plans to call a special session of the Legislature to convene on July 21 to address several issues, including criminal justice reforms. He could add more to the session call in the coming weeks.
Abbott suggested lawmakers consider regulating hemp-based THC in a way similar to the state’s three-tier alcohol system, strictly enforced under an agency such as the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Commission.
Lawmakers should consider enacting “open-container” laws that would prohibit using the product in public or in vehicles as well as age limits, testing requirements and manufacturing restrictions.
The decision closes out months of increasingly heated debate and speculation over whether Abbott would let Texas ban THC, whether the industry should be regulated instead of wiped out, and if the genie that was let out of the bottle in a 2019 farm bill could be forced back in with total prohibition.
It triggered an instant backlash from Patrick, who pointed out in a statement on X that Abbott stayed “totally silent” throughout the session on the bill.
“His late-night veto, on an issue supported by 105 of 108 Republicans in the legislature, strongly backed by law enforcement, many in the medical and education communities, and the families who have seen their loved ones’ lives destroyed by these very dangerous drugs, leaves them feeling abandoned,” Patrick said. “I feel especially bad for those who testified and poured their hearts out on their tragic losses.”
He promised to have “much more to say” at a news conference planned for Monday in Austin.
Abbott’s veto raises the question of what’s next for the 8,500 retailers who have sold the hemp-based products in vape shops, gas stations, coffee shops and brew pubs since they became legal five years ago.
Raids on legal vape shops continue, with police confiscating inventory they allege contains more THC than the law allows. Customers continue to be at risk for felony charges if they buy a product that is too high in THC unwittingly or police erroneously think their legal hemp product is illegal. The stores must do their own self-policing, with no laws against selling near schools or to minors or marketing to young people.
In his veto proclamation Sunday, Abbott acknowledged the industry must be strongly regulated. Texas, unlike other states, does not have age limits, packaging restrictions, or testing or manufacturing requirements.
“The current market is dangerously under-regulated, and children are paying the price,” Abbott wrote.
Allowing the ban to become law, however, would be akin to doing nothing as it gets tied up in courts, he added. If the courts let it happen, he said, it would entrap innocent people.
Among SB 3’s biggest legal problems, Abbott wrote in his statement, is that it would rope in cannabis seeds — sold in stores and used by hemp farmers — that naturally contain THC, which is in opposition to the 2019 federal bill that legalized them, Abbott explained.
“What’s a Texas farmer to do? Trust the federal government’s promise, or fear criminal liabilities from the state?” he wrote.
Veterans using hemp-based THC to treat post-traumatic stress disorder, parents administering it to children for certain types of epilepsy and pharmacists stocking health supplements would all be subjected to criminalization, Abbott said.
“Passing a law is not the same thing as actually solving a problem,” he said. “Texas needs a bill that is enforceable and will make our communities safer today, rather than years from now. ... I look forward to working with them to ensure that we get it right.”
If lawmakers don’t come up with a solution during the special session, the industry, which lobbied for age limits and testing restrictions as an alternative to a full ban, could go another 18 months with no regulatory structure before the next legislative session starts.
The ban would have criminalized possession, sale and manufacturing of consumable THC products. The proposal was considered one of the strongest in the nation and was similar to legislation vetoed by Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis, a Republican, a year ago.
Supporters of the ban say THC should only be legal in Texas when administered through health professionals for those with medical needs who qualify through the state’s narrow medical marijuana program, known as the Texas Compassionate Use Program.
They accuse retailers of carrying products that are often illegally high in THC and selling to minors.
Some supporters included parents who told lawmakers their children suffered psychosis after consuming synthetic THC products. Police detailed how hard it is to enforce regulations on legal THC. Social conservatives said access to intoxicants should be banned while some doctors said THC shouldn’t be easily accessed.
Opponents say prohibition would be a disappointing overreach that defies Texas’ pro-business values and stops residents from accessing life-changing products.
Veterans in particular came out vehemently against the ban, insisting that the state’s recently expanded medical marijuana program doesn’t offer enough options, is not as affordable as hemp-based THC, and doesn’t allow enough of them to qualify for the treatment.
The 2019 loophole
Hemp and marijuana plants are varieties of cannabis. In Texas, products containing THC from marijuana are illegal except for the medical program.
Most THC products derived from hemp plants, however, are legal because of a 2019 state law that allows farming and commercialization of hemp with trace amounts of THC.
Because the law was written for farmers, not retailers, it did not offer the restrictions present in other states’ consumable hemp programs, including strict third-party testing requirements and age limits on purchases.
The 2019 legislation limited the amount of delta-9 THC in hemp plants and products to no more than 0.3% by weight but did not place limits for any other hemp derivatives.
The law removed hemp from the state’s Controlled Substances Act, effectively legalizing all of its derivatives without potency limits on most of them.
In 2023, some lawmakers attempted to ban intoxicating hemp-based products but were unsuccessful.
Considering alternatives in a special session
When lawmakers return for their special session, they could consider a partial ban or an entirely new regulatory structure.
Any push to override the veto would take a two-thirds majority of the House and Senate. The ban passed with fewer than 100 votes in the House in May, less than what’s required for an override.
One idea that gained some traction in the House during the session would save the state’s consumable hemp market from a total ban while reducing it to edibles and nonsynthetic, smokable low-dose flower buds made with hemp grown only in Texas — the market that was initially supposed to benefit from the 2019 farm bill.
Under the proposal, counties could opt out and through elections go entirely “dry,” with no hemp sales, similar to those allowed for alcohol sales. The entire hemp program would be removed from state health officials’ purview and placed under the direction of the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Commission.
A version of that plan still would have wiped out half of the value of products on the market today, but it stopped short of killing the industry altogether.
Staff writer Gromer Jeffers Jr. contributed to this report.

The Latest: From Illinois, Texas House Democrats say their redistricting fight is a fight for America
AUSTIN — Business in the Republican-dominated Texas House screeched to a halt in its third week of a special legislative session Monday when Democrats no-showed a critical vote on a GOP-driven plan to redraw congressional districts to further conservatives’ agenda in Washington.
The Texas House sent state troopers to look for them in all corners of the state after House Speaker Dustin Burrows was unable to call a vote on House Bill 4, by Rep. Todd Hunter, R-Corpus Christi.
A roll call shortly after 3 p.m. revealed that there were only 90 state representatives on the House floor - 10 short of the number legally required to do official business, such as vote on legislation. Those who stayed behind were allowed to leave the chamber while the House stood in recess until 1 p.m. on Tuesday.
“Come back and fulfill your duty, because this House will not sit quietly while you obstruct the work of the people,” Burrows said in remarks from the House floor.
Burrows did not reveal the number of representatives who showed up, but thanked them in remarks from the floor and blasted the “dereliction of duty” shown by those who left.
“Let me begin by commending the members who did show up, those who answered the call, honored their oath and came here ready to work for the people of Texas,” he said. “Your presence speaks volumes. You understand that there are issues before us.”
HB 4, which the Democrats are bent on killing, would shift five congressional districts in Texas from Democrat to Republican – a desire of President Donald Trump as he hopes to maintain control of the U.S. House of Representatives in the 2026 midterm elections.
Democrats say it’s illegal and marginalizes voters of color.
‘We’re happy to go back to the state of Texas this afternoon if the priority is flood relief,” said State Rep. Rafael Anchía, D-Dallas, speaking to The Dallas Morning News near Chicago. “But what we don’t want to do is participate in an illegal act of violating the Voting Rights Act.”
On motions from Rep. Charlie Geren, R-Fort Worth, and more than a dozen other Republicans, the House voted 86-6 along partisan lines to allow Burrows to sign civil warrants for the Texas Department of Public Safety to start looking for Democrats who may still be in the state.
Five Democrats were on the House floor at roll call and voted against sending troopers after their colleagues.
The DPS has the authority to compel their return to the House under threat of arrest as long as they haven’t crossed state lines.
“I’m here to work, and I’m very disappointed in my colleagues who are not here to work. It’s very simple,” said Rep. John McQueeny, R-Fort Worth, who is serving his first term in office.
Other Republicans expressed frustration as well, sending videos from the chamber floor and decrying their decision to flee.
“I do find it funny that I hear from a lot of those colleagues, ‘We don’t want to operate like D.C.,’” said Rep. James Frank, R-Wichita Falls. “Then why don’t they then stop taking orders from D.C.?”
House Democrats Sunday left for Illinois, gathering at a convention center to make their case against redrawing the lines when there was pressing, unrelated business that needed to be done.
During a Monday appearance on CNN, John Bucy said the quorum break is intended to highlight the issue for people across the country.
“This isn’t a Texas Fight. This is an American fight,” Bucy said. “It’s starting in Texas, but if this happens, all Americans will suffer and so we must stop it. And we’re asking all Americans to pay attention to what’s happening, to rise up and help us resist Donald Trump right now.”
The Democrats, some of whom are also in Boston and Albany, N.Y., are expected to stay away from the Capitol until the special legislative session called by Abbott ends on Aug. 19.
Back home on Monday, Republican state leaders railed against the Democrats’ political maneuver, which they said would only delay the inevitable passage of the legislation and kill other bills – including flood relief and property tax reform.
Gov. Greg Abbott continued his public drumbeat, bashing the Democrats for standing in the way of legislation and threatening to call for their removal from office, calling their tactic “an abandonment or forfeiture of an elected state office.”
Bucy said Democrats weren’t afraid of Abbott or Attorney General Ken Paxton, who could start removal proceedings and has threatened to have the Democrats arrested.
“We’re here running into the fight to stand up for our democracy,” Bucy said. “That’s what we’re doing, and we’ll continue to fight as long as it takes. We are here to kill this special session and that’s what we’re going to do.”
Abbott called the special session to deal with a list of 18 items. The bills sitting on the table – flood relief, a ban on retail THC, and other measures – could have, in fact, passed easily had they been brought up before the redistricting map bill, which Democrats warned could blow up the session.
Republicans chose instead to move the controversial new maps first, in what appears to be a tactic to pressure Democrats into staying for the vote – or else take the blame for shirking the flood victims of their due relief and canning other popular measures.
Later on Monday afternoon, about one hundred people showed up to protest outside of the Texas Governor’s Mansion. U.S. Democratic Reps. Greg Casar and Lloyd Doggett, who both represent Austin, spoke at the rally.
The map being considered by the Legislature could force Casar and Doggett to face each other in a Democratic primary for the lone Democratic district in Central Texas.
Neither Casar or Doggett addressed the potential primary at the protest. Instead, they applauded the Democrats who left the state in protest of the map.
Doggett also said that the quorum break has resulted in more Americans being aware of the mid-decade redistricting effort in Texas.
“As far as I’m concerned, they’ve already achieved success in bringing to the attention of the American people that this is even bigger than Texas,” Doggett said.
One of the protesters who showed up Monday was Tammy Conrad, 63, a public school teacher.
Even if the new map ends up passing, despite the quorum break and the protests, Conrad said it’s important to speak out.
“If we don’t stand up every time someone tries to take our power away, we’re not going to have any power left.”
Phillip Jankowski and Joseph Morton contributed to this report.

AUSTIN — Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick promised Monday to keep fighting against the retail consumable hemp industry, accusing Gov. Greg Abbott of turning Texas into a recreational marijuana state by vetoing a statewide ban on THC gummies, vapes and other related products.
“It’s not the state I want,” Patrick, a Republican, said in a news conference at the Capitol. “I don’t want my kids and my grandkids growing up where everybody’s high.”
Abbott vetoed Senate Bill 3 shortly before a midnight deadline Sunday. The GOP governor directed lawmakers to go into a special session of the Legislature later this summer to craft strict regulations on the $8 billion industry.
A ban, Abbott wrote in his veto statement, is unconstitutional because it opposes a 2018 federal farm bill that legalized hemp products and authorized the state to pass its own in 2019.
Texas’ proposed ban would have criminalized sale, manufacture and possession of products containing tetrahydrocannabinol, or THC, the less potent sister to the marijuana plant, that contain any amount of THC — products Abbott argued in his veto statement are legal under federal law, the psychoactive compound in marijuana. That includes products made from hemp.
Abbott announced plans to convene a special session on July 21. He wants legislators to find a way to tax and regulate hemp-derived THC products instead of banning them, potentially through the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Commission as alcohol is regulated.
His decision was a surprise to Patrick, who told reporters that Abbott had told him earlier in the session that the his bill “is fine” and wouldn’t have any problems. He wondered aloud Monday what had changed Abbott’s mind and why the governor hadn’t gotten involved sooner.
Abbott spokesman Andrew Mahaleris said in a written statement that the governor and Patrick are still closely aligned on the issue.
Abbott “has always shared the Lieutenant Governor’s desire to ensure that THC products are not sold to our children and that the dangerous synthetic drugs that we have seen recently are banned,” Mahaleris said. “We should not risk years of potential legal battles when we can fix the bill and protect kids now.”
On Monday, Patrick stopped short of saying he’d kill any bill that wasn’t a ban but warned he would never “gavel down” on allowing the THC market to flourish.
“The best way to protect the adults of the children is to ban the product,” he said. “You cannot regulate 8,000 to 9,000 locations. We do not have enough law enforcement to do so, and they’ll continue to sell it skirting the law.”
Abbott called the regular session’s bill “well-intentioned” but said it has legal problems that would keep it in litigation for years, delaying measures that could regulate an industry he said needed to be reigned in.
The bill opposed federal law and threatened to make felons out of farmers, pharmacists, veterans and parents, Abbott wrote. It would have allowed for the unconstitutional taking of private property — namely from the “responsible” growers, manufacturers and retailers who opened legal businesses and invested millions into the industry that was legal at the time, he explained.
Regulation, not prohibition, is what is on Abbott’s agenda for the special session, so sending another ban to the governor’s desk could be difficult, Patrick acknowledged. Patrick conceded that an override was not likely in the cards.
Texas lawmakers who passed the proposed ban during the regular session, which ended on June 2, said the state’s 8,500 retailers selling the gummies, vapes, drinks and smokable hemp flower are taking advantage of the 2019 state farm bill to set up a market that was never intended by the law.
Lawmakers in the upcoming special session could repeal that bill, Patrick said, or they could send Abbott legislation with so many regulations that it would kill the industry anyway.
Either would be better than creating a framework for more people to access THC for recreational reasons, he said. Leaving it alone is not an option, he warned.
“By this veto, he has now put us in a box where if we do nothing, the status quo continues … which would be devastating to families,” Patrick said. “Or we have to capitulate and vote for the lesser of two really bad evils.”

AUSTIN — Democrats used the opening of the first special session of the 89th Texas Legislature on Monday to stress they would use any tactic necessary to stand up to a proposed redrawing of Texas’ congressional district lines to solidify a GOP majority in Washington.
That could even include fleeing the state to halt legislative action, known as breaking quorum, a tactic employed by Democrats in 2003 to stop the redrawing of district lines and in 2021 to protest changes in voting laws.
“This special session should be focused on rebuilding, not on redistricting,” U.S. Rep. Greg Casar, D-Austin, said at the Texas Capitol. “If Republicans move forward with this reckless plan, Democrats in the legislature will need to do everything they can to stand up for people’s voting rights and to stand up for people all over this country.”
State lawmakers convened at noon Monday for the session, ordered by Republican Gov. Greg Abbott to address several issues including the Hill Country floods and congressional redistricting, among others.
President Donald Trump is pushing for lawmakers to redraw district lines to flip five U.S. House Democratic seats, including three in Houston and one in Dallas, in hopes of maintaining a Republican majority in next year’s mid-term elections.
Democrats in Austin and D.C. warned Monday that forcing them to engage in redistricting now – when the law requires it only be done every decade – could derail a session intended to help victims of the July 4 floods and finish business that couldn’t get done earlier in the year.
“We will need to buy time,” he said, “and that means keeping everything on the table, doing whatever it takes … filibusters, dragging out hearings, quorum breaks, the kinds of tactics that will make sure that we have the time to highlight these issues in front of everyday Americans.”
Democrats have widely criticized redistricting’s addition to a lengthy special session agenda that includes addressing the recent Hill Country floods, regulating hemp-derived THC and property tax relief.
The list of nearly two dozen agenda items also asks legislators to try again on bills that either failed to pass during the regular session earlier this year or didn’t pass muster with the Republican governor once they reached his desk. Lawmakers have already filed at least 150 bills.
“There is more work to be done, particularly in the aftermath of the devastating floods in the Texas Hill Country,” Abbott said in a July statement. “We must ensure better preparation for such events in the future.”
The flash flood that ripped through the Guadalupe River area on July 4 has left more than 100 dead in Kerr County.
Lawmakers are also being instructed to reconsider a failed attempt to toss out the STAAR tests required of public school students, abortion issues that will likely include a ban on the abortion pill, taxpayer-funded lobbyists, and issues regarding transgender rights.
The session may last up to 30 days. Lawmakers are not required to pass everything, but they risk being called into multiple special sessions if they don’t deliver.
The Texas House gaveled out of their opening session on Monday after less than 10 minutes, with much of the action early this week expected to be focused on committee hearings.
In the Senate, Democrats showed their first signs of resistance when what was described as a routine resolution to convene a redistricting committee led to two hours of stern questions over the motivations behind the effort to redraw the state’s congressional districts.
“I am angry,” Sen. Roland Gutierrez, D-San Antonio, said. “I think this is a tremendous waste of time. I think it’s a tremendous waste of resources. I think that there are people that have died all throughout this state in a horrible flood, and that’s the only thing that we should be focusing on.”
Sen Phil King, R-Granbury, said that Democrats’ questions would best be answered in committee hearings. King said that they expect to hold at least four hearings, starting Friday. Some could be virtual.
“Today is not the day to discuss the legalities of a map, how redistricting should be done,” King said. “There’ll be a later time for that. My intent is to look at everything from a race-blind perspective.”
Some residents carried signs in the Texas Capitol on Monday protesting the redistricting push.
“They are only concerned with maximal power,” said 63-year-old Pflugerville resident Jeff Cohen. “That is un-American and it’s wrong. It’s fascism.”
Texas House Democrats said they will not rule out a quorum break to shut down the effort.
“Democrats are going to keep all options open,” said the head of the House Democratic Caucus, Rep. Gene Wu, D-Houston, during a press conference Monday at the Capitol.
The Legislature last redrew district lines in 2021 as part of a regular process that follows the decennial census. The effort was largely viewed as shoring up Republican districts after several Republicans lost seats in the 2018 midterm elections.
Mid-decade redistricting is rare and likely not welcomed by current members of Texas’ GOP delegation in Washington, who could see their solidly red districts watered down as state lawmakers work to build Republican majorities in what are currently heavily Democratic seats.
The Department of Justice has pointed toward the Texas seats as illegal because they created large coalitions of non-white voters, according to a letter the governor cited as his reason for including redistricting. Progressive activists say the letter is a thin veil to disguise a power grab.

Texas Republicans are taking extraordinary measures to quell a quorum break by House Democrats designed to kill congressional redistricting.
The tough approach includes the following:
- Gov. Greg Abbott is trying to remove and replace the absent Democrats from the Capitol, as well as exploring charging them with bribery, if they accept donations to pay the expenses related to their holdout. On Tuesday he filed an emergency petition with the Texas Supreme Court to remove House Democratic Caucus Chairman Gene Wu of Houston and other Democrats from office.
- Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton is investigating Powered by People, the group founded by El Paso Democrat Beto O’Rourke, over reports that they are raising money to support House Democrats who left the state. Paxton has asked the Texas Supreme Court to vacate the seats of 13 House Democrats who broke quorum. And he asked state judges to declare the seats of absent Democrats vacant if they were not back at the Capitol by Friday.
- Sen. John Cornyn has pushed the FBI to help round up House Democrats who are not at the Capitol for the special session. On Tuesday, he said FBI officials had granted his request to help “locate” the Democrats. It’s no secret, however, where most of them are. A large group headed to the Chicago area Sunday. Others are in Boston and Albany, N.Y.
Their hardball strategies depart from how Republicans approached quorum breaks in 2021 and 2003. While they would have executed civil arrests for quorum breakers caught in Texas, they didn’t seriously try to remove anyone from office or enlist federal authorities to intervene once Democrats were out of the state.
What’s different now?
“It comes down to one word, and that’s Trump,” said Vinny Minchillo, a Republican consultant who worked for President Donald Trump’s 2024 presidential campaign. “The president has specifically asked for this and wants to get this done. … It’s as simple as that.”
Trump requested Texas officials redraw its congressional boundaries to help the GOP flip up to five congressional seats now held by Democrats. That would provide Republicans with a cushion going into the 2026 midterm elections.
History shows the party that controls the White House takes losses in midterm elections. Trump wants to avoid that in order to get his agenda completed.
“It’s the razor-thin margins that we have in Congress right now, plus couple that with the directive from the President of the United States, and you’re seeing the elected office holders who are not wanting to be the ones that are holding this process up,” said Republican political consultant Matthew Langston.
Redistricting wasn’t a priority for Texas Republicans until Trump asked for it. And since Trump is the unquestioned leader of the Republican Party and is influential in state and local politics, Texas GOP leaders have to push hard to comply with his requests, analysts say.
“They cannot afford to have a narrative take hold that a Republican stronghold like Texas is allowing a handful of Democrats to throw a temper tantrum,” Langston said.
Andrew Mahaleris, a spokesman for Abbott, didn’t address the Trump dynamic. He said, “Democrats have pulled this stunt one too many times.”
“No more. It is inexcusable to flee the state to avoid the work of the people and hide from debating tough issues, much less delay critical relief to Texans devastated by recent floods, wasting time and taxpayer money in the process,” Mahaleris said in a statement. “Democrats left because they know they are losing the argument. They must return immediately and get back to work.”
Democrats say Abbott and other Republicans are controlled by Trump and no longer have the Texas pride that allows for independent thought.
“There are his private dancers,” said Democratic Party Chairman Kendall Scudder. “Greg Abbott and Ken Paxton will do anything for their East Coast sugar daddy and New York huckster Donald Trump. It’s a really sad display.”
O’Rourke, the former congressman in Paxton’s crosshairs, said he wasn’t worried about the attorney general’s investigation. He said Trump, Abbott, Paxton and Cornyn were worried about the Democrats staying away from the Capitol. His group has countersued Paxton.
“These guys are in full panic mode right now,” O’Rourke said. “If Democrats win the U.S. House majority, we will actually have free and fair elections going forward, so everything is on the line for Trump and he’s really tightening the screws on Paxton, Abbott, Cornyn and on the Republican legislators in Texas.”
State Rep. Chris Turner of Grand Prairie, one of the Democratic lawmakers named in Paxton’s lawsuit, said Paxton is a “terrible attorney general” who is “somewhat good at sending press releases masquerading as court filings.
“In breaking quorum in this special session, I am exercising my legislative rights under the Texas Constitution,” he wrote in a statement. “I am doing the very job the people of House District 101 elected me to do--to fight for them and for the voting rights of all Texans.”
Paxton and Cornyn did not comment for this story. A Paxton campaign spokesperson pointed to his numerous comments on the issue to illustrate his stand against Democrats.
The national political scene is different than in 2021, when Democrat Joe Biden was in the White House. It would have been unlikely that the FBI would comply with Republican requests for assistance in rounding up quorum breakers.
This isn’t the first time Democrats have broken quorum
In 2021, Abbott called two special sessions to get an election bill passed, and another for redistricting. Concern that sweeping changes in Texas election law were discriminatory led Democrats to break quorum that time, and they eventually gave up the strategy and returned to the House floor to fight the losing battle.
Those bills were a reaction to the 2020 elections, where the results in Texas were accepted by Texas Republicans as accurate and fair. Trump argued his loss to Biden was a result of a rigged election, and Legislatures across the country followed up with election law changes that rolled back COVID-era policies that made it easier and more convenient to vote, while toughening provisions to make it harder to commit fraud.
Cornyn did address the 2021 quorum break from the Senate floor. Democrats left Texas for Washington, D.C., as the coronavirus pandemic was still raging.
“They will eventually go home after the cameras leave and after the press loses interest in this political stunt. It’s telling that these Democrats and this House of Representatives chose to race toward TV cameras in Washington rather than present their arguments in the Legislature,” Cornyn said.
“As Texans, standing up to a fight is part of who we are even if you know in the end you may not prevail. But, instead, they turned their backs, hopped on a private jet, and ran from this fight.”
While COVID and the Biden administration may have prevented Republicans from asking the federal government to intervene, there wasn’t the same sense of urgency for Texas law enforcement to get heavily involved.
In 2003, there were early efforts to find the fleeing House Democrats, including then House Speaker Tom Craddick asking then U.S. House Majority Leader Tom DeLay, R-Sugar Land, to enlist the Federal Aviation Administration to track a plane believed to be carrying some Democrats. Craddick also asked DeLay to see if the Justice Department could help bring Democrats back to Texas from Ardmore, Okla.
Later, in a special session, Democratic senators who broke quorum and camped out in an Albuquerque Marriott had their heads on swivels, just in case a Texas law enforcement officer showed up. But that never happened.
It wasn’t necessary.
Democrats have never staged a quorum break that successfully stopped a Republican bill from being passed. The most effective tactic: Keep calling special sessions.
The Trump factor
Trump has said he “deserves” five more Republican congressional seats from Texas.
Abbott has acknowledged that he frequently talks to Trump, but didn’t divulge the details of their conversations about redistricting.
The recent federal, state, local and judicial efforts to move the process forward seemed coordinated.
Abbott added redistricting to a special session agenda after the Department of Justice sent a letter to Abbott and Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton stating that four districts, including Fort Worth Democrat Marc Veasey’s, violate the law because they were drawn with illegal non-white coalitions.
Republicans, including Paxton, have said publicly and in court documents that the districts did not violate the Voting Rights Act of 1965.
After the quorum break, Abbott said on Fox News that population growth made it necessary to redraw congressional boundaries, pointing out the Republican successes in the Rio Grande Valley needed to be reflected in the new boundaries.
Texas Republicans moved forward with redistricting, however, holding several field hearings to get public input, including one last month in Arlington. The hearings were held without the proposed maps or bill.
After the hearings, House Bill 4, authored by Rep. Todd Hunter, R-Corpus Christi, was unveiled. It would shift five congressional districts to Republicans’ favor, and help Trump’s effort to maintain control of the U.S. House of Representatives in the 2026 midterm elections.
The bill was set for a Monday vote, but Democrats left the state to prevent the House from having a quorum.
If the bill isn’t passed before the special session expires on Aug. 19, it dies — for now. Abbott is widely expected to call another special session if needed.
Until then, Republicans are fighting hard to get Democrats in place for a vote.
“The Republicans are going to look at it from the standpoint of we will not be strong-armed and held hostage by a handful of Democrats that are not even in the state,” said Langston, the political consultant. “There will be consequences. I don’t think any of the Republicans are playing around.”
Langston said Abbott is coming off a 2024 primary election cycle where he successfully campaigned to oust eight incumbent Democrats, who, the previous year, voted to block his school choice plan.
“Gov. Abbott is saying, ‘don’t call my bluff on this, because I’m not bluffing,’” Langston added. “He’s not a governor I would mess with right now.”
High stakes for Cornyn, Paxton
The stepped-up activity from Paxton and Cornyn has additional intrigue.
Paxton is challenging Cornyn in next year’s Senate primary. Both would love to have Trump’s endorsement.
The winner of the GOP primary could also benefit from increased political activity in the March primaries and November general elections. If the Republican-driven maps are approved, there will be competitive Senate primaries to determine nominees. Since the races in the Rio Grande Valley will be competitive, even with the new maps, the 2026 elections will have down-ballot candidates powering the overall election turnout.
“It has significant implications on their [Cornyn and Paxton] races to have potentially five open seats where millions of dollars will be spent,” Langston said. “There will be a significant churn within the electorate that is going to have a direct impact on their races. Usually, it’s top down. In this situation, at least in those areas, the congressional races will drive more people out to the polls.”
End game?
It’s still unclear how the quorum break will be resolved.
The legal strategies by Abbott and Paxton could be long shots. It’s also unclear if Democrats can actually get arrested outside of Texas.
Minchillo points out that even though the Texas Supreme Court has ruled in favor of quorum breakers in the past, the all-Republican body could feel pressure to deliver for Trump.
“Remember, the Texas Supreme Court is also an elected position,” he said. “They could be at risk.”
A negotiated settlement is also unlikely, Minchillo said.
“I just don’t know that Abbott’s in a negotiating mood,” Minchillo said. “Whether it’s sooner or later, he’s going to figure out a way to get his way on this.”
One Democrat said, “Republican extremists don’t want a fair fight.”
“There’s a saying that ‘desperate times call for desperate measures’ and Gov. Abbott, Sen. John Cornyn, and AG Ken Paxton (all on our 2026 ballot) are beyond desperate to keep political power,” said Kathleen Thompson, executive director of the liberal group Progress Texas. “They know they will lose in 2026 if they don’t follow marching orders from the president to rig the election now.”
Scudder said Democrats were not backing down amid Abbott’s threats.
“Democrats are going to be playing by the same rulebook that Republicans have,” Scudder said. “Now it’s Greg Abbott’s job to figure out how to mediate this mess, how to negotiate himself into a situation where the government that he controls can be functional.”
When asked about the end game, Scudder redirected the question to Abbott.
“The end game of this is that Donald Trump will take political gerrymandering off of a special session calendar so that we can do the work of the people and get flood relief for the people who need it,” he said.
Dave Carney, Abbott’s political strategist, predicted on its onset that the quorum break would not work.
“They know ultimately they will be back,” Carney said. “They’re going to have to sit there and fight, not just walk away.”
O’Rourke said this time is different.
“There’s a real urgency on both sides,” O’Rourke said. “These 56 people are all that remains between where we are now and the concentration of authoritarian power in the hands of Trump. That’s why I see these guys in full panic mode.”
No matter what happens between now and the end of the special session, the impact of the Texas redistricting saga could play out through 2026 and beyond.

AUSTIN — Ken Paxton is asking that California law enforcement officers be allowed to arrest Texas House Democrats who are staying in the state, according to a lawsuit the attorney general filed Friday.
It’s the second time this week Paxton has petitioned a state to allow civil arrest warrants issued by the Texas House to be enforced outside of state lines. Paxton filed a similar lawsuit on Thursday in Illinois state court against 33 House Democrats, who have been staying near Chicago as they attempt to stop a congressional map from passing.
“Texans are fed up with lawmakers who refuse to do their jobs and instead run away to states like California to exploit radical governors’ broken political systems as a shield,” Paxton said in a statement Saturday announcing the lawsuit.
The Texas House has been at a standstill since Monday after more than 50 Democrats fled the state in protest of a new congressional map that would shift five districts to the GOP’s favor.
The petition naming six House Democratic lawmakers argues that California must honor Texas’ legal acts and judicial outcomes under the “full faith and credit clause” in the U.S. Constitution.
Paxton filed his lawsuit in Tehama County, a Northern California county more than 100 miles from Sacramento. Tehama County supported President Donald Trump in the 2024 presidential election, with the president gaining 64% of the vote while then-Vice President Kamala Harris received 33%.
Harris carried California with 59% of the vote, suggesting Paxton likely filed the petition in a county that might be more receptive to the Republican attorney general’s argument. Paxton filed his lawsuit in Illinois in a county that supported Trump – Adams County. Illinois supported Harris in the presidential election.
House Speaker Dustin Burrows, R-Lubbock, said Friday that more lawsuits like the one filed in Illinois were on the horizon. Republican officials in Texas have been intensifying the pressure in their efforts to bring Democratic lawmakers back to the House.
Burrows said he and Paxton will continue their efforts to bring lawmakers back to Texas.
“All members will eventually have to come back, but the business before the House is too important to wait on the outside political influences pushing these members to delay the inevitable,” Burrows said in a statement Saturday.
In addition to the daily fines and civil arrest warrants Democrats are facing, Paxton and Gov. Greg Abbott have both asked the Texas Supreme Court to expel some of the Democratic members from the Texas House for breaking quorum.
“We are running from nothing,” Rep. Ann Johnson, D-Houston, said Friday at a news conference in California. Johnson was among the six named in Paxton’s lawsuit. “We are here to give hope to others, to stand up and be courageous in this moment.”
The redistricting fight has drawn national attention and could lead to an all-out redistricting battle between the states. House Democrats were in California as state lawmakers there rushed to schedule a special election to rework their congressional maps that will serve as a counter to Texas’ congressional maps.
Within Texas, the congressional redistricting effort has shown to be unpopular. Legislative hearings on the maps have drawn far more people who oppose the maps and the mid-decade redistricting task amid a special session that asks lawmakers to pass legislation in response to the deadly Hill Country floods.
Republicans’ redistricting plan also sparked protests in Dallas on Saturday, with about 100 people gathering in Dealey Plaza to protest the proposed redistricting maps and support the Democrats who left the state.
Protestors, interspersed with tour groups, held signs that said “Don’t tread on Texas Voters” and “No new maps.” Cars driving through the plaza honked in support.
The protest was organized by Indivisible Dallas, which encouraged attendees to register to vote and had tables with information about the redistricting push and gerrymandering. After about 45 minutes, the group marched down Commerce Street to the federal courthouse, then back to Dealey Plaza.
Mindy Miller, 66, was at Saturday’s protest in support of Texas Democrats. The Dallas local said that the fight over redistricting is “fundamental” to democracy.
“Our voice is being diluted,” she said. “My vote doesn’t matter if they’re constantly gerrymandering.”
Jamie Bruner, 55, came to the protest with her neighbor Mary Cato, 76. The two live in Arlington and said they previously attended a hearing at the University of Texas at Arlington, where the redistricting of the Tarrant County commissioners court districts was discussed.
Bruner said redistricting is “cheating” and said it was scary to see how fast the redrawn maps evolved from Tarrant County to the whole state of Texas.
“I’m hoping enough people can stand up and let their voices be heard that they realize that even if they do cheat, we’re still gonna fight,” she said.

Dallas political consultant Kendall Scudder on Saturday was elected chairman of the Texas Democratic Party and immediately promised to build an organization that would make the “Texas working men and women proud.”
Scudder replaces former Cameron County Judge Gilberto Hinojosa, who announced his resignation in November after disappointing losses in the 2024 election. Hinojosa led the party for 12 years.
Since then, party leaders, activists and elected officials have been pondering strategies to start winning statewide elections and protecting Democratic strongholds. Republicans have dominated Texas politics since 2003, when they took control of the entire Legislature and every statewide office. Democrats haven’t won a statewide contest since 1994.
Though chairpersons of Texas political parties don’t have the clout of their counterparts in other states, they play a role in messaging, grassroots activity and fundraising to boost candidates up and down the ballot.
“A lot of people are counting on us to come together and do the right thing and make sure that we’re building a Texas Democratic Party that is worthy of the grassroots in this state,” Scudder said after winning an election held by 121 members of the party’s executive committee. “I know that you’re up for the task…and I can’t wait to work with every one of you to build this Texas Democratic Party that we deserve.”
Democrats agree they need someone to pull together the sometimes disparate factions of the party in order to win elections.
Scudder said he would work toward that goal.
“We’ve made commitments that we’re all going to be working together regardless of outcome,” Scudder said.
It was an easy win for Scudder, who resigned his post on the Dallas Central Appraisal District before the election. He got 65 of 121 votes in the eight-candidate field. Former Annie List’s executive director Patsy Woods Martin was second with 27 votes and Houston consultant Lillie Schechter was third with 26.
Scudder will fill the remainder of Hinojosa’s term, which ends in 2026.

Voting Rights Act doesn’t protect coalitions of racial or ethnic groups challenging political maps, appeals court rules

Coalitions of minority groups cannot band together to claim that political maps constitute discriminatory gerrymandering, the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled in a Galveston County lawsuit.
The 12-6 decision found that the Voting Rights Act’s protections for individual racial or ethnic groups do not extend to multiple groups joining together to claim that political boundaries dilute their votes. The ruling came in a case in which Black and Latino voters jointly sued Galveston County for voter discrimination after the county dismantled a district where people of color made up the majority.
The ruling Thursday reversed a 1988 5th Circuit opinion that found there was nothing that expressly prohibited such coalition claims in Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act, which prohibits voting practices or procedures that discriminate on the basis of race, color, or membership in a language minority group. That decades-old ruling stemmed from a lawsuit alleging that an at-large election system — where all voters elect representatives who serve the entire area, rather than specific geographic districts within it — diluted the votes of a coalition of Black and Hispanic voters.
The court wrote in its new ruling that the Voting Rights Act does not explicitly permit coalition, therefore they have no legal standing.
“Nowhere does Section 2 indicate that two minority groups may combine forces to pursue a vote dilution claim,” Judge Edith H. Jones wrote for the majority. “On the contrary, the statute identifies the subject of a vote dilution claim as ‘a class,’ in the singular, not the plural.”
The ruling only applies to Texas, Louisiana, and Mississippi — the states where the court has jurisdiction. The New Orleans-based 5th U.S. Circuit is known for its ideologically conservative rulings, often pushing legal interpretation to the right. The U.S. Supreme Court has overturned many of its recent rulings. The plaintiffs have not yet announced if they plan on appealing to the Supreme Court.
The new opinion will hinder minority groups from challenging electoral maps, said Nickolas Spencer, a lawyer representing the plaintiffs.
“The Fifth Circuit decision reverses its own precedent in order to make it more difficult for diverse communities to exercise their right to vote,” Spencer said in a statement. “The Court tells Black and Hispanic Americans that their shared harm cannot be [adjudicated] together. In practice this means it often can't be [adjudicated] at all.”

While the majority claims that this “decision will in no way imperil” the success of the Voting Rights Act, six judges remained unsure.
"To imply, as the majority does, that discrimination is permissible so long as the victims of the discrimination are racially diverse, is not only an absurd conclusion but it is one with grave consequences," Judge Dana M. Douglas wrote in her dissent.
The original case was brought by residents of Galveston County joined by the U.S. Department of Justice, three branches of the NAACP, and a branch of the League of United Latin American Citizens. While this decision kills the plaintiffs Section 2 arguments, the lawsuit included two other pathways for litigation that will now be sent back to district court to be resolved.
Redistricting sparked the case. Galveston County commissioners split up Precinct 3, which previously allowed Black and Latino residents to form political coalitions and elect their preferred representatives. After the 2020 census, the precinct, which included diverse areas with a significant Black population, was redrawn into a smaller district in the predominantly white northwestern part of the county. This change ensured that white voters now make up at least 62% of the electorate in each of the four precincts, effectively diluting the electoral power of Black and Latino communities.
Last October, a federal judge ruled that Galveston County’s redistricting maps violated Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act — which prohibits voting practices or procedures that discriminate on the basis of race, color, or membership in a language minority group — by diluting the voting power of Black and Latino residents.
A month later, a three-judge panel from the 5th Circuit agreed but questioned the precedent that allowed minority coalitions to sue, requesting the full court to review the issue.
The new ruling said that allowing coalitions of different racial or ethnic groups to make vote-dilution claims would complicate drawing redistricting maps and inundate courts with cases that are difficult to litigate.
Historically this has been untrue, according to Sarah Xiyi Chen, an attorney litigating the case with the Texas Civil Rights Project. She says that coalition claims are rare because it's difficult to prove that different groups share interests and are jointly discriminated against, making the majority's argument less reflective of the actual context and challenges in Voting Rights Act cases.
Voting rights advocates said it was unjust for the appeals court to overturn its own precedent.
“The Fifth Circuit reversed decades of settled law to deny relief to Black and Latino voters seeking nothing more than equal voting power and a voice in their local government,” said Hilary Harris Klein, an attorney for Southern Coalition for Social Justice who represented the voters who sued. “Plaintiffs proved their case at trial, and in response, the appellate court moved the goalpost.”

ARLINGTON — In a public hearing that oftentimes resembled a political rally, residents from across North Texas on Monday voiced their discontent with the Republican-led effort to redraw Texas’ congressional districts.
A crowd of more than 450 packed the Rosebud at the University of Texas at Arlington while hundreds more waited outside. The crowd cheered and clapped, booed and shouted “Amen” when prompted as lawmakers heard near-universal opposition to the redistricting.
“This is wrong, you know it’s wrong. In your heart, you know it’s wrong,” said Samuel Garcia of Abilene.
President Donald Trump has called on Texas lawmakers to redraw congressional districts in hopes of flipping as many as five districts from Democratic control to Republican, an effort to protect a thin GOP majority in the U.S. House of Representatives during the upcoming 2026 midterm elections.
Get the latest politics news from North Texas and beyond.
Gov. Greg Abbott placed redistricting on the agenda for a special session of the Legislature. While the state’s response to the Hill Country floods was named as the top priority for lawmakers’ limited 30-day session, redistricting has come to dominate the political conversation.
Abbott relied on a July 7 letter from the Justice Department as justification for placing redistricting on the agenda. Democratic lawmakers in both the House and Senate are hoping to hear from the Justice Department attorney who drafted the letter, though House redistricting committee chairman state Rep. Cody Vasut, R-Angleton, said he has yet to get in touch with the lawyer, Harmeet Dhillon.
“I have not received a formal response,” Vasut said. “I received an out-of-office notification.”
Lawmakers on the Senate’s redistricting committee continued to mull whether to subpoena Dhillon. The Senate’s redistricting committee also met Monday in Austin to hear virtual testimony on redistricting.
Dhillon’s letter targeted four districts — three in Houston and one in North Texas — that are illegal because they are composed of a coalition of nonwhite people that make up a majority of their populations. There have been concerns that Dhillon’s reasoning incorrectly interprets a court ruling related to a recent Galveston redistricting lawsuit.
The Justice Department has refused to comment on those concerns.
The Dallas-Fort Worth district targeted by the Justice Department snakes through Dallas and Tarrant counties, creating a district in which roughly 87% of residents are people of color, according to state records.
It is represented by U.S. Rep. Marc Veasey, D-Fort Worth. Veasey was joined by U.S. Reps. Julie Johnson, D-Farmers Branch, and Sylvia Garcia, D-Houston, who addressed the House committee Monday in Arlington.
“Trump has drawn a line in the sand, and it’s time for everybody that believes that what he is doing is wrong to stand up and fight and speak out against this redistricting,” Veasey said at a rally before the hearing.
Since late last week, House lawmakers have heard a chorus of input against the redistricting effort. Lawmakers have been criticized for holding the hearings before any official congressional maps have been presented and labeled eager sycophants for Trump.
“You’re shameless, power-hungry bootlickers for Trump,” Fort Worth resident Mendi Tackett told the committee.
At Monday’s rally, Tarrant County Commissioner Alisa Simmons, whose county commission precinct was redrawn by the commission’s Republican majority in June over her objections, said Tarrant County was Republicans’ “proving ground” for congressional redistricting.
“I’m so glad to see all of you here, right here, in the newly redistricted Precinct 2,” Simmons said. “They jacked with my … seat, OK, and I’m not happy about it.”
House lawmakers did hear what appeared to be the first person to testify in favor of the redistricting plans Monday. That input came from Rich Stoglin, president of the Frederick Douglass Republicans of Tarrant County.
“As a Black American, Afghanistan veteran, a retired department head of the U.S. Department of Justice, I strongly support the Republican redistricting,” Stoglin said over a cascade of boos.
