INGRAM — It was the dead of early morning July 4 when Patrick O’Malley’s house was lifted off the ground and carried 200 feet by the raging Guadalupe River in a remote stretch of the Texas Hill Country.
“The water was just moving so fast,” he recalled on Saturday at an event in Ingram. “I thought three times about jumping out, but there was just no way. I mean, it had just moved my house, you know? I weigh 145. I’m not heavier than a house.”
At least 137 people, including 27 children and counselors at Camp Mystic, died when flash floodwaters raged through communities along the river, through storied towns filled with campers and tourists and homes that have been in families for generations.
More than 100 of the flood’s hardest hit residents, including O’Malley, saw some welcome relief on Saturday when they received their first in what was promised to be a series relief checks from the Vaqueros del Mar, a 15-year-old charity run by country music superstar George Strait – a native of tiny Poteet – and his business partner, Tom Cusick.
“This is the most tragic devastation that I’ve ever seen in Texas, just when you think about the loss of life alone. It’s beyond heartbreaking – truly incomprehensible,” said Gov. Greg Abbott, who met with flood survivors as the checks were being handed out. “We know that in addition to the loss of life, there are so many people like yourselves who are struggling, trying to put their lives back together, dealing with challenges they’ve never experienced before.”
Abbott was joined by Cusick and Texas Division of Emergency Management Chief Nim Kidd at the private event at Ingram Middle School.
“It’s a God thing,” said a grateful Anita Vanklaberen, O’Malley’s mother. “I’ve asked myself so many times, ‘How am I going to help him? How can I help him?’ This is a blessing.”
On the night of the floods, O’Malley, 33, waited alone in his home between Ingram and Hunt – among the areas hardest hit by the deadly Guadalupe River floods – until the sun came up. Then he and his neighbors spent the rest of the morning wading through waist-high waters, floating the street’s stranded children on someone’s boat, to safety on the other side of the road.
Now his house can’t be covered by insurance because his policy didn’t cover floods, and he’s still waiting to find out if he qualifies for help from the Federal Emergency Management Agency.
The private donations will help the construction worker and handyman get back on his feet, O’Malley said – a sentiment echoed by other victims who were receiving funds.
Among the recipients were Dusty Gilliam, whose daughter, Camp Heart of the Hills director Jane Ragsdale, died in the floods. They also included Bear Aspra, whose house was destroyed when the bluff behind it buckled during the rains, and a small boulder rammed through his children’s bedroom.
The four children, ages 2 through 11, were thankfully at their grandparents’ house in nearby Kerrville when the water came up to the steps around 3:30 a.m.
“We just waited until daylight,” Aspra, 39, said. “We didn’t have electricity. We just waited it out. No cell reception, so you can’t call. We were blocked in from the river that was still coming up. Then the sun came up, and it started receding.”
The home has been called a total loss, but it’s been in Aspra’s family for three generations and counting. Clara Aspra, Bear’s wife, is expecting her fifth child – happy news they’d gotten about 12 hours before the walls literally caved in.
Strait’s foundation organized the concert in the first 10 days after the floods, Cusick told the crowd gathered in the auditorium at the middle school. That intimate private benefit dinner and concert, “Strait to the Heart,” took place on July 27 in the exclusive Estancia at Thunder Valley community in Boerne, raising $7 million from donors who purchased tickets at prices starting at $1,000. Local first responders were invited at no cost. The event also collected donations at the door and online.
Strait was joined at the benefit concert by a host of fellow singer-songwriters, including Ray Benson, Wade Bowen, Riley Green, Randy Houser, Kyle Park, Hudson Westbrook and members of Strait’s own Ace in the Hole band.
“The destruction and loss in our community from the recent flood is hard to wrap your head around,” Strait said in a statement promoting the concert. “Our hearts and prayers are with you all. The goal with this event is to raise meaningful, immediate support that can be put directly into the hands of flood victims without delay, while also honoring the first responders that work tirelessly to save lives.”
The first person at the check tables after the official remarks Saturday was Elijah Hoisington, whose trailer at Riverside RV Park in Old Ingram was flooded by the rains.
Hoisington recalls being awakened at 4 a.m. by pounding at the door by members of the Ingram Volunteer Fire Department.
“I opened the door and they said, ‘You need to evacuate. Now,’” Hoisington recalled.
The water was rising visibly, inches every second, it seemed, he said. They were able to get the car out just as the river was seeping into their home.
Now he and his wife are staying at a nearby inn for $500 a week, which is fast depleting the cash they got from FEMA, while they figure out their next move. At 55 and disabled, his retirement is enough to either live on or rebuild – but not both.
“This will help us with our living expenses, which is what we really need the most,” Hoisington said. “They’re calling our trailer a total loss.”
